feed.title: Latest in Anime News by Crunchyroll!

items.title: RECS: 5 Power Rangers Shows To Celebrate Power Rangers Day
items.author: Cezary Strusiewicz
items.description:
Which Power Ranger team has got the most power and force to even up the score?


Power Rangers is coming up on nearly 30 years on television and about as many installments of the franchise. Which were most instrumental to the success of these color-coded Japanese superhero imports here in the West? Hit the jump button to find out the answer.
items.content:
Image via Power Rangers Official

 

Most people tend to celebrate National Power Rangers Day (August 28), by first asking out loud: “Wait, there is a National Power Rangers Day …?” and then realizing that OF COURSE there is a National Power Rangers Day. After all, this is the franchise that changed the game.

 

When Saban Entertainment first took Kyoryu Sentai Zyuranger — part of the Japanese Super Sentai series that’s been on the air since 1975 — and spliced its martial arts/robot-monster fight scenes into original footage of American actors to create a first-of-its-kind hybrid show, they stumbled upon something magical. The resulting Mighty Morphin Power Rangers took the world by storm and spawned sequel after sequel. But which American remix of Super Sentai was the best? The answer will be different depending on who you ask but, for our money, these five series are definitely contenders:

 

Power Rangers Dino Thunder

 

 

The 12th season of Power Rangers, Dino Thunder, felt almost like a soft reboot/remake of Mighty Morphin Power Rangers that simultaneously took itself more and less seriously. On the one hand, the series lampshaded a lot of the sillier elements from the series that started it all like by (lovingly) poking fun at how stereotypically some of its main characters acted in the beginning. But then the series let them grow, taking the best elements of MMPR and refining them into one of the most unforgettable parts of the franchise. A big part of that was due to the return of Jason David Frank as Tommy Oliver but there were other great things about Dino Thunder.

 

The main villain, Mesogog, for one, was more than your typical “evil thing coming down from space to do evil things” bad guy. He still had that over-the-top flare we love and is probably one of the more lethal Ranger foes out there, but there is also a tragedy to him that was a real breath of fresh air. Combined with solid performances from the main cast, Dino Thunder more than earned its shot at the title of the best Power Ranger show ever.
 

Power Rangers RPM

 

 

RPM was one of the earliest Power Rangers shows where the villains felt really scary. Not just cool-looking, or tragic, or well-acted, but actually menacing. Destroying/enslaving 99 percent of humanity is a pretty impressive accomplishment from a franchise that started with a Moon Witch who couldn’t even destroy one town in California.

 

That’s not to say RPM was a sci-fi horror or anything like that. Sure, it was a post-apocalyptic show, but it retained a lot of the signature Power Rangers goofiness, always finding that perfect balance between camp and genuine human moments. The PR vehicles might not have been the best the franchise ever produced, but the weapons of the individual Rangers were what every kid who watched the show wanted for Christmas. Plus, we never got tired of listening to the voice of Venjix, the RPM Big Bad. Still sounds so cool after all these years.
 

Power Rangers S.P.D.

 

 

Disney was on a roll in the early 2000s since Dino Thunder was immediately followed by another amazing Power Rangers show: S.P.D. A police-themed series, one of the greatest accomplishments of S.P.D. is how well it’s managed to juggle its massive cast. With the addition of Rangers like Shadow, Omega, or Nova, the show had nine main characters and still successfully gave each and every one of them as much screen time and attention as they needed for the viewers to care about them.

 

S.P.D. was also expansive in its setting and worldbuilding, and with it taking place in the future and dealing with aliens, it was one of the first Power Rangers shows that had an almost space opera feel to it. The storylines were epic and grand, the characters believable, and there was even a solid mystery element to this incarnation of the Power Rangers. What more can you ask for?
 

Power Rangers Ninja Steel

 

 

Ninja Steel attempted to do a lot of things at once. It sort of tried to capture the tone and energy of Mighty Morphin Power Rangers only with better effects and acting, much like Dino Thunder. But it also took a lot of elements from the original Super Sentai shows, like the cowboy hat-wearing StarNinger from Shuriken Sentai Ninninger, and transplanted them into the show instead of adapting them into a new setting. It seemed like their goal was to celebrate and embrace what made Super Sentai so popular in Japan, which was admirable. The final hook was some of the best effects in all of Power Rangers, particularly with the villains and the attacks.

 

Individually, all of those elements were the peak of Power Rangers’ creativity and storytelling. The problem was that they didn’t always jive together, and that’s what ultimately held the series back from being a masterpiece. All the right parts are still there, though, and you can constantly sense the potential for Ninja Steel to be the greatest Power Rangers show ever. To some, that’s more than enough.

 

Power Rangers in Space

 

 

For many of us, Power Rangers in Space was the first time we started realizing that Power Rangers could be more than just a goofy and colorful pitstop on the road from enjoying cartoons to live-action shows. The sixth Power Rangers season didn’t exactly come without any homework, banking on the viewers’ knowledge of the previous installments of the franchise, but it then brought them all to their most satisfying conclusions. After all, it was the show that made Bulk and Skull … cool, in that one scene? Wait, how on Earth is that possible? It’s not. But In Space it is. (No refunds.)

 

In Space effectively ended the Zordon era of the Power Rangers, and it truly went out with a bang. It felt like the perfect culmination of everything set up by Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Sure, it wasn’t as serious as some of the later shows, but you always got the feeling that In Space was embracing its campier elements out of love for the series that by then had been on the air for five years. Admittedly, some of the appeal of In Space lies in its nostalgia factor and requires you to have an emotional connection with the shows before it. But if you have that, this is the show you will never, ever forget.

 

What's your favorite Power Rangers show? Let us know in the comment section! 

 

 

 

Cezary writes words on the internet. You should follow him on Twitter.

 

Do you love writing? Do you love anime? If you have an idea for a features story, pitch it to Crunchyroll Features!

items.title: High School Life is a Struggle in Heroine Tarumono! TV Anime
items.author: Paul Chapman
items.description:
Main cast, main staff, and teaser PV revealed for upcoming adaptation based on a song by HoneyWorks


It's hard to juggle academic studies and a part-time job managing a male idol duo in Heroine Tarumono! ~Kiraware Heroine to Naishou no Oshigoto~ ("To Become a Real Heroine - The Unpopular Girl and the Secret Task"), a newly announced TV anime based on the song by HoneyWorks. Hit the jump to learn more.
items.content:
It's hard to juggle academic studies and a part-time job managing a male idol duo in Heroine Tarumono! ~Kiraware Heroine to Naishou no Oshigoto~ ("To Become a Real Heroine - The Unpopular Girl and the Secret Task"), a newly announced TV anime based on the song by HoneyWorks. The main staff has been revealed for the series, including:

 

  • Original work, music: HoneyWorks
  • Director: Noriko Hashimoto
  • Series composition, screenplay: Yoshimi Narita
  • Character design, chief animation director: Kaori Ishii
  • Art director: Ryousuke Obakata
  • Color design: Tomoko Yamazaki
  • Director of photography: Yomogiko Murano
  • Editor: Gou Sadamatsu
  • Sound director: Yukio Nagasaki
  • Music: Moe Hyuga
  • Animation producer: Noritomo Yonai
  • Animation production: Lay-duce
  • Planning, production: Shunsuke Saito
  • Production: Heroine Tarumono Production Committee

 

The main cast of Heroine Tarumono! ~Kiraware Heroine to Naishou no Oshigoto~ includes:

 

  • Inori Minase as Hiyori Suzumi.
  • Kōki Uchiyama as Yuujirou Someya (LIP x LIP)
  • Nobunaga Shimazaki as Aizou Shibasaki (LIP x LIP).
  • Ayane Sakura as Juri Hattori.
  • And Saori Hayami as Chizuru Nakamura.

 

 

The story of Heroine Tarumono! ~Kiraware Heroine to Naishou no Oshigoto~ follows Hiyori Suzumi, a high school student who moves to Tokyo and takes a part-time job as an assistant manager to the male idol duo LIP x LIP in order to make ends meet. Hiyori soon learns that it's tough to juggle work, school life, and club activities, especially when the talent she's managing are also her classmates.

 

 

Heroine Tarumono! ~Kiraware Heroine to Naishou no Oshigoto~ is scheduled to begin broadcasting in Japan in April of 2022. An official website and Twitter feed (@HoneyWorksMovie) have also been published for the series.

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

Copyright notice: © Heroine Tarumono Production Committee

 

 

---

Paul Chapman is the host of The Greatest Movie EVER! Podcast and GME! Anime Fun Time.

items.title: Students Jockey for Position in Gunjou no Fanfare TV Anime
items.author: Paul Chapman
items.description:
Main cast and staff revealed for original series about young men studying to be professional horse racers


Gunjou no Fanfare ("Fanfare of adolescence"), an original TV anime about a trio of young men training to be professional jockeys at a prestigious horse racing academy, has been announced, and the main cast, the main staff, and a teaser trailer have all been revealed for the series. Hit the jump to learn more.
items.content:
Gunjou no Fanfare ("Fanfare of adolescence"), an original TV anime about a trio of young men training to be professional jockeys at a prestigious horse racing academy, has been announced, and the main cast, the main staff, and a teaser trailer have all been revealed for the series. The main staff includes:

 

  • Director: Makoto Kato
  • Character design: Hiro Kanzaki
  • Music: Hiroyuki Sawano
  • Animation production: Lay-duce

 

The cast of Gunjou no Fanfare includes:

 

  • Shogo Yano as Yu Arimura.
  • Shimba Tsuchiya as Shun Kazanami.
  • And Natuski Hanae as Amane Grace.

 

競馬学校で騎手を目指す少年たちの青春群像劇
TVアニメ『 #群青のファンファーレ 』
2022年春放送開始

【スタッフ】
監督 #加藤誠
キャラクターデザイン #かんざきひろ
音楽 #澤野弘之
アニメーション制作 #レイデュース

【キャスト】#矢野奨吾#土屋神葉#花江夏樹https://t.co/kQpF0zJ8r8 pic.twitter.com/VLhMrzzjCe

— オリジナルTVアニメ『群青のファンファーレ』公式アカウント (@fanfare_anime) August 28, 2021

 

Set in a demanding school that only admits 10 to 20 students per year, Gunjou no Fanfare is a youth drama that follows the lives of three young men - a boy who formerly belonged to an idol group, a boy who was raised on a remote island, and a boy from England whose parents dictate his future for him - as they train to become professional horse racing jockeys. Can they make it through three years of schooling that tests not only their motor skills and academic prowess, but also their physical attributes as well?

 

 

Gunjou no Fanfare is scheduled to begin broadcasting in Japan during the spring season of 2022. An official website and Twitter feed (@fanfare_anime) have also been published for the series.

 

Sources:

MoCa

Comic Natalie

 

Copyright notice: © Fanfare Anime Project

 

 

---

Paul Chapman is the host of The Greatest Movie EVER! Podcast and GME! Anime Fun Time.

items.title: BEASTARS Creator Paru Itagaki Draws Official Illustration for The Suicide Squad Film
items.author: Daryl Harding
items.description:
Itagaki said it was "dazzling to see the villains leave their moral values behind and go on a rampage"


BEASTARS creator Paru Itagaki already has a handle on drawing some monstrous creatures in her own series, which is probably the reason why Warner Bros. went to the award-winning manga creator to draw an official illustration for The Suicide Squad's Japanese release. Check out Itagaki's poster after the jump!
items.content:
BEASTARS creator Paru Itagaki already has a handle on drawing some monstrous creatures in her own series, which is probably the reason why Warner Bros. went to the award-winning manga creator to draw an official illustration for The Suicide Squad's Japanese release. Itagaki's poster shows Harley Quinn wearing her manic grin and King Shark just wanting food.

 

 

Itagaki said she was "captivated by the unique villains" in the film, and that it was "dazzling to see the villains leave their moral values behind and go on a rampage."

 

The Suicide Squad opened in Japan on August 13 and has since made 390 million yen in the region, this is in contrast to Birds of Prey, which made 510 million during its run, and the first Suicide Squad in 2016, which made 1.76 billion yen. The dip is likely due to both the Delta variant of COVID-19 rampaging across Japan, deterring people from going to theaters, and the demographic likely to see the film not the usual type to go to the cinema.

 

Source: Comic Natalie

 

----

Daryl Harding is a Japan Correspondent for Crunchyroll News. He also runs a YouTube channel about Japan stuff called TheDoctorDazza, tweets at @DoctorDazza, and posts photos of his travels on Instagram.

items.title: Next Baki Anime Series Launches on Netflix in September
items.author: Daryl Harding
items.description:
Baki Hanma fights on next month


The Japanese Netflix Anime Twitter account revealed yesterday that Baki's fight will continue on in September – only a month away! The next season of Baki, titled Baki Hanma and subtitled Son of Ogre, will see the titular character do his best to beat the world's number one fighter – his father! More after the jump!
items.content:
The Japanese Netflix Anime Twitter account revealed yesterday that Baki's fight will continue on in September – only a month away! The next season of Baki, titled Baki Hanma and subtitled Son of Ogre, will see the titular character do his best to beat the world's number one fighter – his father!

items.title: The Faraway Paladin TV Anime 2nd PV Announces October 9 Premiere Date in Japan
items.author: Mikikazu Komatsu
items.description:
Yuu Nobuta (Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear)-directed fantasy will be simulcast on Crunchyroll


The official website for the forthcoming TV anime adaptation of Kanata Yanagino's fantasy light novel series The Faraway Paladin has started streaming a 60-second second PV to announce its premiere date in Japan, October 9, 2021. Check out the latest information after the jump!
items.content:
The official website for the forthcoming TV anime adaptation of Kanata Yanagino's fantasy light novel series The Faraway Paladin has started streaming a 60-second second PV to announce its premiere date in Japan, October 9, 2021. The TV anime is set to premiere on TOKYO MX (22:00), AT-X (23:30), and BS Nittele (24:00) on the day.

 

The clip also introduces the anime's OP theme song "The Sacred Torch" performed by singer Hikaru//'s solo project H-el-ical//. In 2007, she was selected from among 30,000 applicants at the Sony Music audition held for the theme song for the anime film The Garden of Sinners. As Hikaru, she joined the vocal unit Kalafina from its second single "sprinter/ARIA." One year after Kalafina's disbandment was announced, she made her major debut under the name H-el-ical// from NBCUniversal Entertainment Japan in May 2020. As her fourth solo single, "The Sacred Torch" is set to be released on November 3, 2021.

 

 

2nd PV:

 

 

Meanwhile, Nagi Yanagi is confirmed to sing the ED theme song "Shirushibi." It will be released as her 22nd single on November 3, 2021. 

 

【 OP&EDアーティスト解禁 】
本日一挙に解禁✨

OPテーマ「The Sacred Torch」
H-el-ical//

EDテーマ「標火」
やなぎなぎ

本日公開されたPVでは
OPテーマを聴くことができます！https://t.co/lYVBIi7Wg1#最果てのパラディン#faraway_paladin pic.twitter.com/DjXWgOURse

— TVアニメ「最果てのパラディン」 (@faraway_paladin) August 28, 2021

 

 

It was also announced that Aoi Yuki (Madoka Kaname in Puella Magi Madoka Magica) will be playing the role of Gracefeel, the god that the protagonist Will swore an oath to, and Hiroki Takahashi (Katsuya Jonouchi in Yu-Gi-Oh!) is cast as Stagnate, the immortal god who will be Will's adversary.

 

 

【 追加キャスト解禁 】

グレイスフィール： #悠木碧
スタグネイト：　#高橋広樹

＼キャストコメント公開中／https://t.co/lVu2KsWtvG#最果てのパラディン#faraway_paladin pic.twitter.com/geetyZmbRq

— TVアニメ「最果てのパラディン」 (@faraway_paladin) August 28, 2021

 

 

New character visuals:

 

【 新規キャラクタービジュアル公開 】

メインキャラクターの新規ビジュアルを公開✨
それに合わせて公式HPもリニューアルオープン！

▼公式HPhttps://t.co/KaVFC7Sv7J#最果てのパラディン#faraway_paladin pic.twitter.com/RxK0DxFat0

— TVアニメ「最果てのパラディン」 (@faraway_paladin) August 28, 2021

 

 

Main voice cast:

 

  • Will: Maki Kawase (Yuna in Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear)
  • Blood: Katsuyuki Konishi (Tengen Uzui in Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba)
  • Mary: Yui Horie (Wiz in KonoSuba)
  • Gus: Nobuo Tobita (Kamille Bidan in Mobile Suit Zeta Gundam)
  • Menel: Ayumu Murase (Shoyo Hinata in Haikyu!!)

 

 

 

 

The TV anime The Faraway Paladin will be also simulcast on Crunchyroll this fall. Yuu Nobuta (Kuma Kuma Kuma Bear) serves as director at Children's Playground Entertainment.

 

 

Synopsis:

 

In the ruined city of the dead far from human civilization lives a single human child named Will. He is raised by three undead: Blood the heroic skeleton warrior, Mary the ladylike mummy priestess, and Gus the crotchety ghost wizard. The three of them teach the boy what they know and pour their love into him. One day, the boy begins to wonder, "Who am I?" Will uncovers the mysteries of the undead hidden in this faraway land. He learns of the love and mercy of good gods, as well as the paranoia and madness of evil gods. And once he learns it all, the boy embarks on the path to becoming a Paladin.

 

 

1st PV with English subtitles:

 

 

Key visual:

 

 

Sources: "The Faraway Paladin" official website / Twitter

 

©Kanata Yanagino, OVERLAP/The Faraway Paladin Prodcution Committee

items.title: Total Number of Audiences for The Prince of Tennis Musicals Surpasses Three Million
items.author: Mikikazu Komatsu
items.description:
One of the most successful 2.5D shows was launched in 2013


The official website for the musical adaptation project inspired by Takeshi Konomi's The Prince of Tennis sports manga announced on August 25 that the total number of audiences for the musical shows had surpassed a milestone of three million during the latest show "Seigaku vs Fudomine" of its fourth season. Hit the jump for more details.
items.content:
The official website for the musical adaptation project inspired by Takeshi Konomi's The Prince of Tennis sports manga announced on August 25 that the total number of audiences for the musical shows had surpassed a milestone of three million during the latest show "Seigaku vs Fudomine" of its fourth season.

 

The site writes, "It's all thanks to all of you who have supported us. Again, we would like to express our gratitude." In celebration of the three million mark, a special curtain call was held after the performance at 13:30 on August 27. Hikaru Imamaki, who is now cast as the protagonist Ryoma Echizen, wrote on Twitter after the curtain call, "I'm so happy to be part of its 18-year history!"

 

The Prince of Tennis musical adaptation project was launched in April 2013 and has performed more than 1,900 times across Japan. It has become one of the most successfull 2.5 dimensional show based on a popular Japanese manga. Its ongoing latest show "Musical The Prince of Tennis 4th Season Seigaku vs Fudomine" is scheduled to be performed at Nihon Seinenkan Hall in Tokyo until August 29.

 

 

"Musical The Prince of Tennis 4th Season Seigaku vs Fudomine" digest:

 

 

Key visual:

 

 

本日もご来場ありがとうございました！！！????

今日はですね
テニミュ累計動員者数300万人突破記念のスペシャルカーテンコールがありました????????

18年の歴史の中にいられる事がとても嬉しいです！
あと2日。全力で挑みます。
よろしくお願いします????

司会進行をしてくれた2人と????????‍♂️????

#テニミュ pic.twitter.com/knIZwbKqqQ

— 今牧輝琉 (@p_man1120) August 27, 2021

 

 

Source: "The Prince of Tennis" musical project site, Hikaru Imamaki Twitter

 

© Takeshi Konomi/Shueisha, NAS, The New Prince of Tennis Project

© Takeshi Konomi/Shueisha, Tenimu production Committee

items.title: Yui Horie Releases My Senpai Is Annoying ED Theme on October 16
items.author: Mikikazu Komatsu
items.description:
The song will be aired for the first time on the radio on September 3


Voice Actress Yui Horie has announced that her new digital single "Niji ga Kakaru made no Hanashi" (A Story till the Rainbow Comes) is set to be released on October 16, and that it will be featured as the ED theme for the fall 2021 TV anime My Senpai Is Annoying, in which he is also cast as one of its main characters, Yuto Sakurai. Check out her new visuals after the jump!
items.content:
The official website for voice actress Yui Horie has announced that her new digital single "Niji ga Kakaru made no Hanashi" (A Story till the Rainbow Comes) is set to be released on October 16, and that it will be featured as the ED theme for the fall 2021 TV anime My Senpai Is Annoying, in which he is also cast as one of its main characters, Yuto Sakurai. It will be her second anime tie-up song of this year, following "Adieu," the second ED theme for the Shaman King TV anime. 

 

Along with the OP theme song "Annoying! San-san Week!" performed by the four main voice cast members, a part of this song was already introduced in the anime's first PV posted yesterday. Also, the song will be aired for the first time on her radio program "Horie Yui no Tenshi no Tamago" at 25:00 on September 3 (JST).

 

Her new artist visual for the single is also revealed. She wears a winter scarf, but as she says on Twitter, "The outfit is out of season...," it was probably taken on a very warm day.

 

 

新アーティストビジュアル公開????

▷堀江由衣 Official web sitehttps://t.co/jHDIdatC0q#堀江由衣 #虹が架かるまでの話 pic.twitter.com/pdPN83UKjZ

— 堀江由衣STAFF (@horieyui_staff) August 27, 2021

 

 

"Niji ga Kakaru made no Hanashi" digital single jacket:

 

 

TV anime "My Senpai Is Annoying" PV:

items.title: EDENS ZERO Franchise Launches Its Official YouTube Channel
items.author: Mikikazu Komatsu
items.description:
The channel will deliver the latest information about the TV anime and games


The official portal site for Hiro Mashima's space opera manga EDENS ZERO announced on August 27 that its official channel "EDENS ZERO Channel" has launched on YouTube. The guests of its first episode are Mikako Komatsu (Rebecca Bluegarden) and Shiki Aoki (Homura Kôgetsu). Learn more after the jump!
items.content:
The official portal site for Hiro Mashima's space opera manga EDENS ZERO announced on August 27 that its official channel "EDENS ZERO Channel" has launched on YouTube to deliver the latest information about the TV anime and games.

 

The guests of its 13-minute first episode are Mikako Komatsu (Rebecca Bluegarden) and Shiki Aoki (Homura Kôgetsu), who worked together for the first time in this anime (However, due to the COVID-19 pandemic, they have only met face-to-face once at a studio this year). The two share many behind-the-scenes stories about the production of the anime, provided by the staff and voice cast members.

 

For example, Shiki confessed that Miyuki Sawashiro's performance as Valkyrie was so wonderful that she cried a lot while watching her rehearsal video. Before the actual voice recording session, she had to watch the video over and over again, while crying, until she got used to it in order to concentrate on her own performance.

 

 

 

【#EDENSZERO チャンネル本日始動‼】#エデンズゼロ 公式Youtubeチャンネル、本日始動❣

TVアニメ、ゲーム、原作等「EDENS ZERO」の様々な情報をお届け‼

記念すべき第一回は #小松未可子 さんと #青木志貴 さん????　1回目からトンでもない展開に????

登録、お願いします????https://t.co/I0n7z3Y4Se pic.twitter.com/mI1EafmVzn

— EDENS ZEROプロジェクト公式 (@EDENSZERO_PJ) August 27, 2021

 

 

The TV anime EDENS ZERO premiered in Japan on April 10, 2021, and has been also streamed on Netflix worldwide since August 26.

 

 

Trailer:

 

 

Key visual:

 

 

Source: "EDENS ZERO" official portal site

items.title: Sumire Uesaka Looks Gorgeous in The Great Jahy Will Not Be Defeated! 2nd Cour OP Theme Visuals
items.author: Mikikazu Komatsu
items.description:
The song is written/composed by Kenichi Maeyamada (aka Hydain)


Voice actress Sumire Uesaka has announced that her next 12th single "Seikatsu Konkyu Dame dinero" (Living in Poverty, Give Me Money) is set to be released on October 27, 2021, and that it will be featured as the second cour OP theme for the TV anime The Great Jahy Will Not Be Defeated! Check out her gorgeous visuals for the single after the jump!
items.content:
Voice actress Sumire Uesaka has announced that her next 12th single "Seikatsu Konkyu Dame dinero" (Living in Poverty, Give Me Money) is set to be released on October 27, 2021, and that it will be featured as the second cour OP theme for the TV anime The Great Jahy Will Not Be Defeated! She has also voiced one of the anime's main characters, Magical Girl. 

 

The song is written/composed by Kenichi Maeyamada, aka Hydain, a music creator who has been active in a wide range of Japanese entertainment industries. He says, "I am honored to be working with Uesaka-san for the first time on this song. The song has become one that is filled with energy. Extraordinary development, too much energy! Sumipe-san is amazing at singing it! The lyrics are written from Jahy's point of view, but also has a universal message. In today's world where we can't speask aloud, shake the vocal cords of your heart! Dame dinero!"

 

Uesaka's official website has unveiled the two CD jacket photos and her new artist visual for the single. In the visuals, she wears a striking dress made up of "commonplace objects," such as pull-tab crowns, aluminum corsets, and collars made with packing material. 

 

 

 

First press limited edition CD jacket:

 

 

Standard edition:

 

 

──────────ଘ¥ଓ#上坂すみれ 12th Single

The TV anime adaptation of Wakame Konbu's comedy manga The Great Jahy Will Not Be Defeated!, produced by Silver Link, premiered in Japan on August 1, 2021, and has been simulcast on Crunchyroll to its members in North America, Central America, South America, Europe, Africa, Oceania, the Middle East, and CIS. 

 

 

Synopsis:

 

In the Dark Realm, the Great Jahy was only second to the demon king. Feared by all, she was supposed to be just enjoying being endlessly willful and hedonistic, when a magical girl attacked her and blasted her to the human realm. Forced to live in poverty, her days consist of working in a bar while living in a tiny apartment without a bathroom. Blowing both pity and the demand for rent away, her ambitions are grand: Restoring the Dark Realm!
